abstract: The Digital Domain column last Sunday, about privacy on Facebook, referred incorrectly to people who can view information in a member’s profile. Although the member’s friends can see such information, so can people who belong to a school, workplace or geographic network on Facebook that the member may join. (The member, however, can change default privacy settings to deny that access to those on the network.).
snippet: The Digital Domain column last Sunday, about privacy on Facebook, referred incorrectly to people who can view information in a member’s profile. Although the member’s friends can see such information, so can people who belong to a school, workplac...
lead_paragraph: The Digital Domain column last Sunday, about privacy on Facebook, referred incorrectly to people who can view information in a member’s profile. Although the member’s friends can see such information, so can people who belong to a school, workplace or geographic network on Facebook that the member may join. (The member, however, can change default privacy settings to deny that access to those on the network.)

headline.main: Corrections: When Everyone’s a Friend, Is Anything Private?
